    Creating combine datacards from Pepper outputs

    Now that we have produced histograms, applied corrections and computed systematic uncertainties, it is time for the final step: making the fit!

    We will use the standard CMS fitting tool, called combine. Its documentation can be found here.

    In order for combine to do its job, it needs two things: a datacard, which is a text file containing information about the different processes, categories, and uncertainties we consider, and ROOT files containing the shape templates that we want to fit to our data. We will use the number of jets as our binning variable - since you already have this variable included in your histograms, your shape templates are already there! They need to be brought into the correct form, however.

    The export script and the combine config

    Writing the datacard and getting the shape templates into the right format for combine to read can be a bit of a pain, and is very error-prone and time-consuming when done by hand. Because of this, the git repository already contains a script that takes care of the brunt of the task. You can find it under fit/export_for_combine.py.

    The actual information on the fit setup is stored in the file fit/combine_config_dilep.hjson.

    Question

    Open fit/combine_config_dilep.hjson and try to roughly understand its structure!

    How many and which categories does the current fit configuration contain?

    Which systematic uncertainties are included?

    To-do

    Create datacards and shape template files from your most recent outputs by running

    python export_for_combine.py combine_config_dilep.hjson <path/to/your/histogram.coffea> <output_folder_name>

    For now, use the njet histogram after the Has btag(s) cut (so, at the end of the analysis).

    Look at the output folder the script created! There should be a text file there called all.txt - this is the datacard. Open it and have a look!

    About combine datacards

    Your output directory should have a text all.txt. This is a datacard, containing text information about the samples, bin counts, and uncertainties. To load information about shape uncertainties, it links to a corresponding root file, e.g. ee.root.

    In the next section, we will see how to go from these files to a measurement.

    Question

    For now, try opening the one txt datacard and one root file. You can use a TBrowser or uproot for the latter. Do the contents make sense?

    Adding more systematics

    The systematics that you implemented in Exercise 3 are not yet included in the datacard. Let us fix that.

    To-do

    Modify the systematics section of combine_config_dilep.hjson to include the additional systematic uncertainties, namely:

    • the muon reconstruction and identification scale factors,
    • the parton shower weights for ISR and FSR,
    • (if you computed it only) the uncertainty on pileup reweighting.

    You can do this by simply copying and modifying some of the other lines. The hist parameter must correspond to the name of the systematic uncertainty in the input histogram.

    If you are done, re-run the script and see what changed in the datacard!
